uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools
Interface Layer

All Known Implementing Classes:
SimpleLayer, testLayer, ShapeLayer, randomLayer, MapExtentLayer, CircleLayer, MixedLayer, PolygonLayer
public interface Layer

A layer contains geographic feature of some kind that can be displayed in a map. Anything that wants to end up on screen in a Viewer will need to implement this.

Understanding Layers is key to understanding how geoTools works and if you plan to add a new type of geographic feature then the layer interface is the place to start.

Layers are held in one or more themes which in turn are held in one or more viewers.

If you do write your own type of layer then extending simpleLayer will make life easyer for you.

Method Detail

paintScaled

public void paintScaled(GeoGraphics gg)
Paints the layer to the screen. The very hart of the layer mechanism, paintScaled is where layers have to do most of their work.
Calling and filling in of this method is handled by the theme to which the layer has been added.

The GeoGraphics object should provide you with everything needed to plot a feature onto the screen.
Inside gg you can use or not use the facilies provided as you see fit.

gg.getGraphics() A Graphics object to which you should direct all of your output. gg.getScale() A Scaler which you can use to convert real world(tm) co-ordinates into on screen co-ordinates for use with the Graphics g object. gg.getShade() shade A Shader, if you want to color your features based on a value (perhaps from the data peramiter) then use shade.getColor(double value); to obtain the colours. gg.getGeoData() A GeoData object, use this if your features have id's then you can obtain a coresponding value from data. gg.getStyle() style A style with hints on how to display the features

paintHighlight

public void paintHighlight(java.awt.Graphics g,
                           Scaler scale,
                           int id,
                           ShadeStyle style)
Highligts the specified feature. A simple version of paintScaled, this is used to paint a single feature in some way that make it stand out from the other features.
Todate, this has been by using a bright red colour, a more user-definable system maybe implemented in later versions.
Again the only thing that sould call this is a Theme
Parameters:
g - A Graphics object to paint the highlighted feature to.
scale - A scaler that can be used to scale the feature.
id - An int for the ID of the feature to be highlighted.
style - A style with hints on how to display the highlight
See Also:
Theme

paintSelection

public void paintSelection(java.awt.Graphics g,
                           Scaler scale,
                           int[] ids,
                           ShadeStyle style)
Dispays the specified features. A simple version of paintScaled, this is used to paint a group of features in some way that make it stand out from the other features.
Todate, this has been by using a bright red colour, a more user-definable system maybe implemented in later versions.
Again the only thing that sould call this is a Theme
Parameters:
g - A Graphics object to paint the selected features to.
scale - A scaler that can be used to scale the feature.
ids - An int[] for the IDs of the features to be shown as selected.
style - A style with hints on how to display the selection
See Also:
Theme

getBounds

public GeoRectangle getBounds()
Gets the smallest GeoRectangle that will contain all of this layers features. When implementing this, set up a new GeoRectangle that will define the region of interest for your layer.

Returns:
GeoRectangle A GeoRectangle that will contain all of the features in the layer; For layers without geographic bounds it should return a null e.g. a scale bar or a norh arrow.

getBoundsOf

public GeoRectangle getBoundsOf(int id)
Gets the smallest GeoRectangle that will contain the feature identified by the given ID.
Parameters:
id - The id of the feature to fetch the bounds of
Returns:
GeoRectangle The bounds of the requested feature
Since:
0.6.5

getBoundsOf

public GeoRectangle getBoundsOf(int[] id)
Gets the smallest GeoRectangle that will contain the features identified by the given IDs.
Parameters:
id[] - The ids of the features to fetch the bounding rectangle
Returns:
GeoRectangle The bounds of the requested feature
Since:
0.6.5

getID

public int getID(GeoPoint p)
gets the ID of the feature that can be assosiated with a given point. For example, the ID of a feature that contains the point.
Parameters:
p - The GeoPoint of a location to test for a feature.
Returns:
int The id of the feature assosiated with this point; return 0 if no feature is associated.

getIDs

public int[] getIDs(GeoRectangle box,
                    int mode)
gets the ID of the features that can be assosiated with a given region. For example, the IDs of all features that are within the rectangle.
Parameters:
box - The GeoGeoractangle of the region of the query.
Returns:
int[] The ids of the features assosiated with this region; returns new int[0] if no features are selected.

getID

public int getID(double x,
                 double y)
A convinence method that is the same as getID(GeoPoint) but witout having to construct a geoPoint.
Parameters:
x - a double, the x co-ordinate.
y - a double, the y co-ordinate.
Returns:
int The id of the feature assosiated with this point; return 0 if no feature is associated.

getStatus

public int getStatus()
get the status of this layer: in most cases this should be Layer.COMPLETED to show that the layer is ready to paint. Where a layer has posponed loading it can be Layer.PENDING, Layer.LOADING, Layer.ERRORED or Layer.ABORTED

setStatus

public void setStatus(int status)
set the status of this layer: in most cases this should be Layer.COMPLETED to show that the layer is ready to paint. Where a layer has posponed loading it can be Layer.PENDING, Layer.LOADING, Layer.ERRORED or Layer.ABORTED
When the status becomes COMPLETED for the first time, a LayerChangedEvent is sent. Should only be called by the Layer Producer or the Layer itself

addLayerChangedListener

public void addLayerChangedListener(LayerChangedListener lcl)
Adds a LayerChangedListener to the layer, typicaly called by Theme writen for you if you extend simpleLayer();

removeLayerChangedListener

public void removeLayerChangedListener(LayerChangedListener lcl)
Removes a LayerChangedListener to the layer, typicaly called by Theme writen for you if you extend simpleLayer();

notifyLayerChangedListeners

public void notifyLayerChangedListeners(int reason)
Notifis all LayerChangedListener's that this layer has been modified. It should only normaly be called by the layer itself. To make life easyer it has been writen for you if you extend simpleLayer. Make sure you call it if some aspect of your feature changes such that you would like it to be re-painted.

Parameters:
reason - An int code indicating what type of change has occured; LayerChangedEvent provides GEOGRAPHY and DATA as two constants to use as reason codes.
See Also:
LayerChangedListener

setName

public void setName(java.lang.String n)
Set the name of this layer so it can be viewed in toString() and getName() later on.
Parameters:
n - the name of the layer

getName

public java.lang.String getName()
Get the name of this layer. If it has not been set in setName(), then the layer will be called "Unknown".

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Get the name of this layer. If it has not been set in setName(), then the layer will be called "Unknown".
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
